Explanations about Options.-p:
Attach to the process with the process ID pid and begin tracing. The trace
 may be terminated at any time by a keyboard interrupt signal (CTRL-C). strace
 will respond by detaching itself from the traced process(es) leaving it (them)
 to continue running. Multiple -p options can be used to attach to many
 processes in addition to command (which is optional if at least one -p option
 is given). -p "`pidof PROG`" syntax is supported.
Explanations about Options.-f:
Trace child processes as they are created by currently traced processes as a
 result of the fork(2), vfork(2) and clone(2) system calls. Note that -p PID
 -f will attach all threads of process PID if it is multi-threaded, not only
 thread with thread_id = PID.
Explanations about Options.-v:
Print unabbreviated versions of environment, stat, termios, etc. calls.
 These structures are very common in calls and so the default behavior displays
 a reasonable subset of structure members. Use this option to get all of the
 gory details.

so_51557238: Why is the DEBUG trap executed more times than expected?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_109151: trap '{ type -p -- "${BASH_COMMAND%% *}" >&3; } 3>&2 2> /dev/null' DEBUG
set -o functrace -o xtrace

BASH_ENV=<(cat <<'EOF'
  trap '{ type -p -- "${BASH_COMMAND%% *}" >&3; } 3>&2 2> /dev/null' DEBUG
EOF) bash -o functrace -x your-script

BASH_ENV=<(cat <<'EOF'
  { trap '{ cmdpath=$(type -p -- "${BASH_COMMAND%% *}")
      } 2> /dev/null' DEBUG;} 2> /dev/null
EOF) PS4='+[$cmdpath] ' bash -o functrace -x your-script

BASH_ENV=<(cat <<'EOF'
  { trap '{ hash -- "${BASH_COMMAND%% *}";} 2> /dev/null' DEBUG;}2>/dev/null
EOF) PS4='+[${BASH_CMDS[${BASH_COMMAND%% *}]}] ' bash -o functrace -x your-script

ul_477330: #!/bin/bash

PS4=''
set -x

echo 'This is a script that has debugging turned on'

$ bash script.sh
echo 'This is a script that has debugging turned on'
This is a script that has debugging turned on

$ PS4='' ./script.sh
echo This is a script that has debugging turned on
This is a script that has debugging turned on

$ PS4='$(date +"%T: ")' ./script.sh
21:08:19: echo 'This is a script that has debugging turned on'
This is a script that has debugging turned on
21:08:19: echo 'Now sleeping for 2 seconds'
Now sleeping for 2 seconds
21:08:19: sleep 2
21:08:21: echo Done
Done

Explanations about Options.-p:
Select by PID. This selects the processes whose process ID numbers appear in
 pidlist. Identical to p and --pid.
Explanations about Options.--ppid:
Select by parent process ID. This selects the processes with a parent process ID
 in pidlist. That is, it selects processes that are children of those listed in
 pidlist.

Answers.MP Summary: or  any situation  where  you want to make sure you're doing a clean install of your dependencies. It  can  be  significantly  faster  than  a  regular  npm  install  by  skipping   certain user-oriented  features.  It  is  also  more strict than a regular install, which can help catch errors or inconsistencies caused by the incrementally-installed  local  environments of most npm users. In short, the main differences between using npm install and npm ci are: · The project must have an existing package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json. · If dependencies in the package lock do not match those in package.json, npm ci will exit with an error, instead of updating the package lock. · npm ci can only install entire projects at a time:  individual  dependencies  cannot  be added with this command. · If  a  node_modules  is  already present, it will be automatically removed before npm ci begins its install. · It will  never  write  to  package.json  or  any  of  the  package-locks:  installs  are essentially frozen. See Also · npm help install · npm help package-locks April 2020                                  NPM-CI(1)

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_109151: Bash option to get resolved executable path?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_109151: trap '{ type -p -- "${BASH_COMMAND%% *}" >&3; } 3>&2 2> /dev/null' DEBUG
set -o functrace -o xtrace

type -p

BASH_ENV=<(cat <<'EOF'
  trap '{ type -p -- "${BASH_COMMAND%% *}" >&3; } 3>&2 2> /dev/null' DEBUG
EOF) bash -o functrace -x your-script

BASH_ENV=<(cat <<'EOF'
  { trap '{ cmdpath=$(type -p -- "${BASH_COMMAND%% *}")
      } 2> /dev/null' DEBUG;} 2> /dev/null
EOF) PS4='+[$cmdpath] ' bash -o functrace -x your-script

so_21190771: #

export PS4="\$LINENO> "   # Now, I'll see the line numbers while debugging
set -xv                   # Debugging is turned on
....
#
# Done with debugging
#
set +xv                   # Debugging is turned off

so_20955251: while ((i < halflen))
do
    if [[ ${strtochk:i:1} == ${strtochk:j:1} ]];then
        ((i++))
        ((j--))

        break
    fi
done
